de.esoco.lib.expression

Interface BinaryFunction<L,R,O>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.util.function.Function<L,O>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    BinaryFunction.ThrowingBinaryFunction<L,R,O,E>, BinaryPredicate<L,R>, BinaryPredicate.ThrowingBinaryPredicate<L,R,E>, ObjectSpaceResolver, ObjectSpaceResolver.DeleteResolver, ObjectSpaceResolver.GetResolver
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractBinaryFunction, AbstractBinaryPredicate, BinaryFunctionChain, BinaryFunctionChain.LeftFunctionChain, BinaryFunctionChain.RightFunctionChain, BinaryFunctionGroup, BinaryPredicateChain, Cast, ClassPredicate, ClassPredicate.HasBaseClass, ClassPredicate.HasClass, Comparison, Comparison.ElementOf, Comparison.EqualTo, Comparison.GreaterOrEqual, Comparison.GreaterThan, Comparison.LessOrEqual, Comparison.LessThan, Comparison.Matching, Comparison.SameAs, DualFunctionChain, ExceptionMappingBinaryFunction, ExceptionMappingBinaryPredicate, ExtractString, GetElement, GetElement.GetField, GetElement.GetListElement, GetElement.GetMapValue, GetElement.GetRelation, GetElement.GetRelationValue, GetElement.ReadField, InvokeMethod, ObjectSpaceResolver.PutResolver, Print, RelationTypeFilter, SetElement, SetElement.SetListElement, SetElement.SetMapValue, SetElement.SetRelationValue
    Functional Interface:
    This is a functional interface and can therefore be used as the assignment target for a lambda expression or method reference.

    @FunctionalInterface
public interface BinaryFunction<L,R,O>
extends Function<L,O>
    Interface for binary functions that derived their result from two input values. The generic parameters define the types of the left and right input values (L, R) and the resulting output value (O). For most implementations the easiest way to implement a binary function will be to create a subclass of AbstractBinaryFunction.

    To increase the usefulness of binary functions this interface extends the standard (unary) Function interface which contains a single-argument Function.evaluate(Object) method. To support the unary evaluation this interface defines the method getRightValue() that can be overridden by subclasses to provide a default right value, for example. Applications that only want to use the direct evaluation of binary functions may ignore the methods for unary usage.

    • Method Detail

      • unchecked

        static <L,R,O,E extends java.lang.Exception> BinaryFunction<L,R,O> unchecked(BinaryFunction.ThrowingBinaryFunction<L,R,O,E> fChecked)
        Takes a binary function that throws an exception and returns it as a function that can be executed without checked exception. This method is mainly intended to be used with lambdas that throw exceptions.
        Parameters:
        fChecked - The checked binary function to wrap as unchecked
        Returns:
        The unchecked binary function

      • evaluate

        default O evaluate(L rLeftValue)
        Default implementation that invokes evaluate(Object, Object) with the return value of getRightValue() as the right argument.
        Parameters:
        rLeftValue - The input value of the function
        Returns:
        The resulting (output) value (may be NULL)
        See Also:
        Function.evaluate(Object)

      • evaluate

        O evaluate(L rLeftValue,
           R rRightValue)
        Evaluates the binary function on the left and right input values and returns the resulting value.
        Parameters:
        rLeftValue - The left value to evaluate
        rRightValue - The right value to evaluate
        Returns:
        The result of the evaluation

      • from

        default <A,B> BinaryFunction<A,B,O> from(Function<A,? extends L> fLeft,
                                         Function<B,? extends R> fRight)
        Returns a new function object that evaluates the output values received from two other function with this binary function. Implementations should typically subclass AbstractBinaryFunction which already contains an implementation of this method.
        Parameters:
        fLeft - The function to product the left input values with
        fRight - The function to produce the right input values with
        Returns:
        A new instance of DualFunctionChain

      • getRightValue

        default R getRightValue()
        Returns the right value of this binary function. The default implementation always returns NULL.
        Returns:
        The right value

      • withRight

        default <T> BinaryFunction<L,T,O> withRight(Function<T,? extends R> fRight)
        Returns a new function object that evaluates this function with the original input value and a right value from the output value received from another function. Implementations should typically subclass AbstractBinaryFunction which already contains an implementation of this method.
        Parameters:
        fRight - The function to produce the right input values with
        Returns:
        A new instance of DualFunctionChain
